What Makes a Good Gauge?

Resolution

Accuracy (location)

8


MEASUREMENT SYSTEM ANALYSIS


Resolution / Discrimination


Resolution is the size of the data category when the total measurement system is considered. The smallest difference distinguished by Measurement System.

Gages with inadequate resolution are only useful for indicating conformance or nonconformance.

Rule of thumb: the resolution of a measurement should be one-tenth of the process range.

What is the resolution of the top scale of the ruler?

Of the bottom scale?


9

MEASUREMENT SYSTEM ANALYSIS


Accuracy – Bias

Bias is the difference between the observed average of measurements and the master average of the same parts.

Bias is often referred to as “accuracy”.

Because accuracy has several meanings in literature, bias is the preferred term.


Bias

Reference Value

Observed Value

10

MEASUREMENT SYSTEM ANALYSIS


Accuracy – Bias


Acceptance Criteria for Bias: In general, less than 10% of process tolerance.


Cgk = (0.1 *T - |xbar– xm|)/(3*s)

T : “Product Tolerance” or “Process Tolerance” xm: Reference Value

s: standard deviation of measurement data.


Acceptance Criteria: Cgk ≥ 1.33 (Generally)

11

MEASUREMENT SYSTEM ANALYSIS


Accuracy – Linearity


Linearity is the difference in the bias values of a gage through the expected range of the gage.

Bias

Lower Part of the Range

Bias

Higher Part of the Range

Reference Value

Observed Value

Reference Value

Observed Value

Larger


12

MEASUREMENT SYSTEM ANALYSIS


Accuracy – Stability


Stability is the variation in the measurements obtained on the same master part when one characteristic is measured over an extended time period.

Stability is often tracked on a control chart and corrected with periodic calibration.


Recalibration


13

MEASUREMENT SYSTEM ANALYSIS


Stability – Control Chart Example


14

MEASUREMENT SYSTEM ANALYSIS


Accuracy – Correlation

Correlation is a linear association of two variables, e.g., two different measurement methods or two different sites.


15

MEASUREMENT SYSTEM ANALYSIS


Precision – Repeatability


Repeatability is the variation in measurements obtained with one gage when used several times by one operator while measuring one characteristic on one part.

Repeatability is variation usually caused by the device.


Cg = (0.2 * T)/(6 * s)

T : “Product Tolerance” or “Process Tolerance” s: standard deviation of measurement data.


Acceptance Criteria: Cg ≥ 1.33 (generally)

Repeatability


16

MEASUREMENT SYSTEM ANALYSIS


Precision – Reproducibility


Reproducibility is the variation in the average of the measurements made by different operators using the same gage when measuring one characteristic on one part.

Oper. C

Oper. A

Oper. B

Reproducibility is operator to operator or alternatively system to system variation.

25

MEASUREMENT SYSTEM ANALYSIS


Gage R&R – Cookbook Method

  1. Calibrate the gage or verify that the last calibration is valid.

  2. Collect 10 samples representing the full range of process variation.

  3. Identify operators that daily use this measurement method

  4. Setup the gage study data sheet using Stat > Quality Tools > Gage Study

    > Create Gage R&R Study Worksheet

  5. Have the operator measure all samples in blind, random order.

  6. Have the other operators measure the samples, in blind, random order.

  7. Repeat steps 5 & 6 for three cycles. Try to randomize the operator order, too.

  8. In Minitab run the following two analyses.

    • Stat > Quality Tools > Gage Run Chart

    • Stat > Quality Tools > Gage R&R Study (Crossed)…

  9. Analyze the results for measurement system capability.

  10. Determine appropriate follow-up actions

MEASUREMENT SYSTEM ANALYSIS


MS Metrics – Number of Distinct Categories



Number of Distinct Categories is the number of distinct categories within the process data that the measurement system can discern.

The number of distinct categories is a measure of the resolution

The number of distinct categories is a function of the Repeatability & Reproducibility

Acceptable: > 4

Acc. under certain conditions : 3 - 4


DC#1

DC#2

DC#3

DC#4

X

Xmeasured

X

Where is measured X? X is somewhere in this distinct category, but I don’t know where.

Gage R&R Study for Measurement

Summary Report

Can you adequately assess process performance?

Study Information

Number of parts in study Number of operators in study Number of replicates

10

3

The measurement system variation equals 20.3% of the process variation. A historical standard deviation is used to estimate the process variation.

(Replicates: Number of times each operator measured each part)

Comments

Can you sort good parts from bad?

The measurement system variation equals 24.3% of the tolerance.

Total Gage

Reprod

Is MS capable?

%Process Var

%Tolerance

General rules used to determine the capability of the system:

<10%: acceptable

10% - 30%: marginal

>30%: unacceptable

Examine the bar chart showing the sources of variation. If the total gage variation is unacceptable, look at repeatability and reproducibility to guide improvements:

  • Test-Retest component (Repeatability): The variation that occurs when the same person measures the same item multiple times. This equals 63.0% of the measurement variation and is 12.8% of the total variation in the process.

  • Operator and Operator by Part components (Reproducibility): The variation that occurs when different people measure the same item. This equals 77.7% of the measurement variation and is 15.7% of the total variation in the process.

Source is Repeatability or Reproducibility?

51

MEASUREMENT SYSTEM ANALYSIS


P/T, P/SV and P/PV

P/T (%Tolerance)

The most common estimate of measurement system precision Compares gage precision to the tolerance requirements

P/T is okay if the gages are used to classify production samples

P/SV (%R&R) – Best for Lean Six Sigma

Measures how the gage performs compared to the gage study variation Best estimate for performing process improvement

Be careful. Gage Study Variance is not necessarily representative of the true process variance.

P/PV (%R&R) – Best for Lean Six Sigma

Measures how the gage performs compared to the process variation

Be careful. Gage Study Variance is not necessarily representative of the true process variance.

P/PV equals P/SV when the variation in your gage samples represent true

52 process variation.


Gage Variance

Observed Values

MEASUREMENT SYSTEM ANALYSIS


Demo #3 (Homework)


Product A Product B Product C

Range of Samples collected for Study


P/SV is determined to be about 8% when parts are drawn from a broad range of products.

Is this gage capable? Why or why not? What suggestions might you make?

Manufacturing process facts (given):

Process Target = 320 Standard Deviation = 4 Tolerance = 40

Gage R&R Study:

The following samples were chosen for the R&R STUDY. These samples represent the full tolerance range

295, 300, 305, 310, 315, 320, 325, 330, 335, 340, 345

P/SV is determined to be 15%

Is this gage capable? Why or why not? What suggestions might you make?

Remember:


The observed process variance is dependent on the measurement system. The best the observed process can perform is equal to the gage variance


59

MEASUREMENT SYSTEM ANALYSIS


What Do You Do With a Poor Gage?


If Reproducibility is Dominant

Determine if the same procedure is followed by all operators. Educate operators in “best practice”

Consider automating some of the most variable steps If Repeatability is Dominant

If possible, then repair, replace or adjust the equipment

 Average   Individuals

n

A temporary solution is averaging multiple measurements (Remember the Central Limit Theorem?)


Example:



  

9

 1 

GageR&R.mtw

MEASUREMENT SYSTEM ANALYSIS


Homework / Exercise


Analyze the following dataset: GageR&R.mtw Is this an acceptable measurement system?

Where is the variability in the measurement system coming from?

Can you make recommendations regarding how this system could be improved?

Hint: Try to eliminate the major portion of the Part*Operator interaction term and re-analyze the data.



61

MEASUREMENT SYSTEM ANALYSIS


Attribute R&R



62

MEASUREMENT SYSTEM ANALYSIS


Purpose of Attribute R&R


Process Assessment

To assess your inspection or workmanship standards against your customer’s requirements

To determine if inspectors across all shifts, machines, etc. use the same criteria to determine good from bad

To quantify the ability of inspectors to accurately repeat their inspection decisions

To identify how well these inspectors are conforming to a “known master” including customer and producer bias

Process Improvement

Discover where training is needed, procedures are lacking, and/or standards are not defined.


63


Setup

MEASUREMENT SYSTEM ANALYSIS


Attribute R&R – Method

Select 30 parts from the process; 50% passers, 50% defects

If possible, select borderline or marginal good and bad samples Select inspectors; fully trained and qualified

Execution

Each inspector inspects the parts in random order to determine pass and fail. Each inspector repeats the inspection.

Analysis

Enter the data into the spreadsheet AttributeR&R.xls to determine the effectiveness of the measurement system.

Evaluation

Document the results.

Implement appropriate actions to fix the process if necessary. Rerun the study to verify the effectiveness of the fixes.


64

MEASUREMENT SYSTEM ANALYSIS


Attribute R&R – Terminology


Attribute Data – qualitative (go / no go) data that can be tallied for recording and analysis

Attribute Measurement System – a measurement system that compares each part to a standard and accepts the part if this standard is met

Customer Bias – operator has a tendency to hold back good product

Master Value (Reference Value) – the average value of a characteristic on a part measured by a gage of high accuracy

Producer Bias – operator has a tendency to pass defective product


65

MEASUREMENT SYSTEM ANALYSIS


Attribute R&R – Exercise

Divide into groups of three. Each person is a visual inspector on a different shift.

Your job is to determine if M&M’s being processed are “shippable” to the customer. Your management told you that the customer desires a colorful quality product.

Your instructor will pass out the samples.

30 pieces have been identified to use in this Attribute R&R process. Line up the samples in a row to keep track of the sample number. (Ordinarily they would be randomized)

Independently have each inspector document his findings twice on paper. Ensure the trials are independent

Use AttributeR&R.xls to determine the screen and appraiser scores. Interpret the results and recommend actions.

You have 30 minutes for this exercise.

Attribute R&R – Other Ways

If your data is stacked, you can also use Minitab Assistant for Attribute Agreement Analysis.

MEASUREMENT SYSTEM ANALYSIS


Check

Mix of Items

Status

i

i

Description

Attribute Agreement Analysis for Result

Report Card

It is good practice to have a fairly balanced mix of Pass and Fail items. Your data shows that you have 70% Pass items and 30% Fail items. If you have a small percentage of items of one type, you reduce your ability to assess how well the appraisers rate that type of item.

Accuracy and Error Rates

The accuracy and error rates are calculated across all appraisals. Suppose you test 50 items, 25 Good and 25 Bad, and 3 appraisers test each item 2 times.

To calculate the accuracy and error rates, you need to determine the total number of appraisals:

  • Overall accuracy and error rates: (50 items x 3 appraisers x 2 trials) = 300 appraisals

  • Good items rated as Bad: (25 items x 3 appraisers x 2 trials) = 150 appraisals

  • Bad items rated as Good: (25 items x 3 appraisers x 2 trials) = 150 appraisals

  • Items rated both ways: (50 items x 3 appraisers) = 150 appraisals

Overall % Accuracy: If 240 appraisals match the standard, the accuracy rate is: (240/300) x 100 = 80%

Overall Error Rate: If 60 appraisals do not match the standard, the error rate is: (60/300) x 100 = 20%

Good rated Bad: If appraisers rate a Good item as Bad 30 times, the misclassification rate is: (30/150) x 100 = 20%


Bad rated Good: If appraisers rate a Bad item as Good 15 times, the misclassification rate is: (15/150) x 100 = 10%


Rated both ways: If appraisers rate 15 items inconsistently across trials, the misclassification rate is: (15/150) x 100 = 10%

Assistant - Report Card

How are Accuracy Rate and Error Rate are calculated?

Is sample selection balanced? Pass vs Fail.

Consider the following when assessing how the measurement system can be improved:

  • Low Accuracy Rates: Low rates for some appraisers may indicate a need for additional training for those appraisers. Low rates for all appraisers may indicate more systematic problems, such as poor operating definitions, poor training, or incorrect standards.

  • High Misclassification Rates: May indicate that either too many Pass items are being rejected, or too many Fail items are being passed on to the consumer (or both).

  • High Percentage of Mixed Ratings: May indicate items in the study were borderline cases between Pass and Fail, thus very difficult to assess.

Where to focus for improvement?

Is MS capable? For what?

Is Inspection an Answer?



For a 90% inspection efficiency, it takes five consecutive inspectors

77 to reduce defects to 10 ppm.

Inspection and Sigma Level


For a 90% efficiency, it takes six inspectors to achieve 6 Sigma quality levels.
